name: Assassins -  Is this Prestige Class Extinct?
author: grizzled_dwarflord

posts.author: grizzled_dwarflord
posts.content:
Are assassins pretty much a gimmick class at this stage in NWN?  I can't think of a reason any longer to choose an Assassin over a Rogue in any situation.  Maybe to avoid xp penalty, but I don't find xp penalties a compelling reason any more.  

Rogue Advantages
4 more skill points per level.  
Rogues can obtain early access to Crippling Strike that doesn't require special circumstances to fire like the Death Attack.  
Rogues receive more bonus Feats, to include Epic Dodge.  
Rogues receive same amount of sneak dice.
Rogues get Evasion for Free

What does the Assassin offer on the other side?
Invis -- big whoop.  
Ghostly Visage -- oh boy
Darkness - Meh
Improved Invis -- Really the only redeeming aspect of the class.  However, Rogues can access this via items, scrolls, Dust of Disappearance, etc.
Bonus Feats come every 4 levels.  A 19th level Rogue would have 4 bonus feats.  A 19th level Assassin only 2.
Bonus Feats are meh -- with the exception of Great Dex, the rest are trash.  
Death Attack -- since the mini nerf to the Death Attack first flurry (and now only the first actual attack), this has even more diminishing returns.

So, if any of you are like me, and always feel jilted like a bride left at the altar when playing an Assassin, what could be done to restore some health, wellness, and balance to the Assassin class.  I'm asking about things within reason, that are balanced and wouldn't make it better than the Rogue, but maybe more on equal footing.  Looking for thoughts, opinions, suggestions, and good discussion.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
As far as I know the only problem with the assassin class in EE is that the death attack paralysis is limited to one attempt per round. Prior to that you attempted a paralyzing attack every time you targeted a flat footed creature. And you would do so with every attack in the actual flurry of attacks you attacked with. That would of course multiply the chance of succeeding with the paralysis compared to the single attempt after EE.

One question is if you have to play EE or if you can stick to 1.69. That depends on where you play.

Even after EE assassin has its uses. One is to avoid a multiclass xp penalty as was mentioned above. You still get most of the rogue skills as class skills, "SA" damage and UD, so it may serve well as tumble class in some builds.
Most of the spell like abilities are so-so. Ghostly visage can be of some use early on, but soon becomes obsolete. Improved invisibility is far better than the one rogues can cast with UMD. It lasts longer and is far more difficult to dispel. Cast from a sequencer it lasts so long that it almost becomes a permanent feature.
The feature I value the most as a builder is the Great dexterity bonus feat. It enables builds that end at dex 40 and have a high warrior like like AB.

After EE the scales definitely have tilted in favor of rogue.
Despite the similarities between the classes, one should treat assassin as something different. You can use the class to achieve results that are impossible with the rogue class. And rogue will give builds you cannot make with the assassin class alone.

If you want ED, crippling strike and more skills, build with rogue.
If you want high AB, DA paralysis, 50% concealment and no XP penalty in the build, assassin can be the class to use.

That makes the Assassin Evil.

So, with that, how can one make the Assassin better?

Make his ability to murder better. I mean, we already have such powerful things as Dev Crit, HiPS, Epic Dodge, etc.

I propose adding Murder Strike - which makes the Death Attack deadly again.

Just like Dev Crit, it threatens death with the Death Attack, with the DC increasing with level of the Assassin.

At first the DC should be rather low - corresponding to Assassin being able to be taken at level 6.

From there, it should increase.

5.       Epic Prowess can be an Assassin Bonus Feat


Okay, so I took everybody’s suggestions into consideration.  Some of them were rather good, I just don’t know how hard it would be to manipulate the mechanics.  So, rather than make Assassins like Rogues (because we do want them to be different, and we don’t want to diminish the genius of the Rogue), or grant Assassins SD qualities (I agree with Orion in that HiPS should be a trademark for the SD class), or grant them more of a melee presence, I’ve elected to enhance the things they were already good at.
 
Someone mentioned Poisons.  Check!  Increase durations.  Some PWs do this.  I think WoG use to, not sure if they still do.
 
At 4th level, the Assassin gains an Assassin Bonus Feat: Stealthy.  I thought this was a fair compromise, and in keeping with the Assassin mythos of dark art training.
 
At 6th level, the Assassin, forever training in the Dark Arts, acquires the ability to cast Ultravision.  I’m not sure how hard it would be to add this as a Feat in the game.  Obviously we’re talking haks at this point.  Caster level equal to Assassin Level (like it is for their other Spell Abilities.
 
Next, we increase Darkness, Invis, and Improved Invis uses.
 
Allow Epic Prowess to be selected as an Assassin Bonus Feat.
 
I do like the Murder Strike concept.  Maybe as a unique bonus feat?  That would require some engineering.  That can be a backburner project.
 
There.  That still keeps them uniquely Assassin.  It’s reasonable, it’s not OP, while still giving them unique advantages over their Rogue counterpart.  It doesn’t come across as unbalancing (unless maybe in a low-magic world, and then what classes aren’t unbalances in a low-magic world?)
 
Now, who wants to be the one to propose this to Beamdog?  And if that fails, your admins on your favorite PW?

Basically, any time the assassin's target would be denied her Dexterity bonus to AC (whether she actually has a Dexterity bonus or not), the assassin's attack deals +1d6 points of damage, This extra damage increases by
+1d6 points every other level (+2d6 at 3rd level, +3d6 at 5th level, and so on).

As one can see, the Assassin is one of the oldest of Classes, in the same category as Monk.  It has existed down through the different editions (making a rather odd appearance in 4th Edition in an edition of Dragon Magizine) and appearing as well in 5th.

The beginning Assassin was not originally what we would label "evil" - though that alignment did not exist back then.  It was considered Neutral.

The 1st Edition rules did not automatically make the Assassin evil, either.  Rather, it tried to keep PC Assassins Neutral in alignment, though they could not be good.  It did not rule out evil ones, however, and most NPC Assassins were indeed evil in alignment.

3rd Edition introduced the evil only rules.  This is obviously because of the rule stipulation that to become an Assassin, one had to kill someone soley for the purpose of becoming an Assassin.

It is specifically spelled out as a condition for taking the Prestige Class :

Special: The character must
kill someone for no other reason
than to join the assassins.

As such, yes, taking levels in the Prestige Class Assassin in 3rd edition requires one to have killed someone for the sole purpose of becoming an Assassin.

Since we are indeed playing 3rd Edition rules in NWN, and the Assassin Prestige Class is based on these rules, it is important to keep this in mind when considering the class, regardless of personal preference or opinion.

And with that, I rest my case, based on the Official Sources, from the rulebooks themselves.

This might be resurrecting a dead thread, but some other ideas:

Add some Assassin specific bonus feats and change bonus feat progression to one at level 10 and then one every 3 levels (ideas for bonus feats) - this would change total potential bonus feats from 5 bonus feats to 7; changing the selection allows for some more flexibility in character building and some of the options are specifically to address some of the weaknesses; Feats that can only be taken at epic levels could not be taken at Assassin 10 unless character was already an Epic Character. Also by forcing a choice it avoids the feeling from a player of having a wasted feat as a class default. 
  • Improved Evasion - (new to Assassin, but would need to be modified since Assassin doesn't qualify for Evasion)
    • [ul]
  • Would need to make Evasion a pre-requisite so a decision/investment in a synergistic class is forced (Evasion : SD 2, Monk 1, Rogue 2); this Feat currently doesn't have pre-requisites as the only classes that qualify already get Evasion at earlier levels.
  • By avoiding giving Assassins Defensive Roll to qualify for Epic Dodge then this could still encourage a SD 5 + Assassin combo and allowing qualifying for ED without needing the 10 levels of SD. More flexibility to maximize Assassin levels, since 5 SD levels would still allow for 28 Assassin levels to be taken (changing bonus feat progression to every 3 levels means that last bonus feat would be at 28 instead of 30).
[li]HiPS [/li]
  • Similar to the 3.5e change to give Assassins the feat at Assassin level 8; however, by making this an optional bonus feat it allows some more flexibility in character building as those who choose to pair Assassin with SD would deprioritize this, those who want to save a class could instead take an Assassin to get HiPS
  • Really helps Monk+Assassin combos as Monk gets Evasion to qualify for Assassin Improved Evasion and still get HiPS without needing the 1 level investment in SD
[li]new Improved Death Attack - Target now dies instantly on failed fortitude save for Death Attack (similar to Dev Crit, no death spell immunity); even when target succeeds the save they are still paralyzed (unless immune to paralysis).[/li]
  • Death Attack was supposed to be an option to Kill or Paralyze but the NWN engine has some limitations; this would be a way to buff DA
  • Immunity to paralysis still avoids paralysis but wouldn't provide immunity to the death effect. Immunity to crit and/or Immunity to sneak damage still negate.
  • Make 8d6 DA (must be DA and not SA) a pre-requisite to avoid it being taken prior to Assassin 15; so should become available at similar character level as Dev Crit could be. 
[li]new Premeditated Assault - Allows Assassins to add their INT modifier to their damage rolls.[/li]
  • This would be overall base damage increase and not just Death Attack; helps make Assassins more effective against Crit/Sneak Immune. From a lore perspective makes use of Assassin training.
  • Also opens some interesting possibilities for Wizard/Assassin combos
[li]Dual-wield - (like Ranger ability) - acts like a combo Ambidexterity/TWF, but as a single feat. Would carry same armor restrictions (light armor or robes only) (Does not qualify for ITWF).[/li]
  • Intent here would be to allow for some STR/INT Assassin DW builds that could potentially mix Wizard+max BAB class (Fighter, Barb, BG) instead of needing to depend on Ranger or 15 DEX + dedicating feats. 
  • Will not qualify for ITWF, but allows for some Dual Wield RP scenarios without taking heavy feat investment or Ranger class; avoiding ITWF requires builders to make choices on how important that extra off-hand attack is. Rangers get it for free helps them be separated from Assassin.
[li]Venom Immunity - (like Druid feat) immune to all poisons[/li]
  • I don't have a use for this in mind, but seems like it could fit the class and maybe some industrious builders out there could think of something
[li]Great Intelligence - (new for Assassin)[/li]
[li]Epic Prowess - (new for Assassin)[/li]
[li]new  Trained Killer - allows the assassin to use full death attack damage (just DA, not SA) against Favored Enemies without sneak restrictions. [/li]
  • Would apply only to Favored Enemies (Ranger or Harper Scout). Assassin would not be able to select Favored Enemies so is useless without spending levels on another class.
  • This forces builders to consider trade-offs of adding more FEs versus higher DA damage, but giving Assassin some extra synergy with Ranger
  • Death Attack paralysis does not apply (unless conditions for it were met normally), this is just for enhancing damage against FEs.
  • For PVM could pick enemies that are normally sneak/crit immune for enhanced damage; for PVP would allow for higher damage in combat by changing FE selection - thus avoiding a universally better build but still allowing for some creativity in the build
[/ul]
 
The following two feats would help offset the fewer skills by giving some options to boost specific skills through custom feats (not as flexible as Rogue, but a way to offset the fewer skill points).

    • [ul]
  • This could be potentially added to the Shadow Dancer pool of feats as well, and then modified to use the sum of SD + Assassin levels

  • This could be potentially added to the Ranger pool of epic feats as well, and then modified to use the sum of Ranger + Assassin levels

  • If pool above still feels underwhelming then could potentially give Assassin first rank for free at level 10.
